conclusion: To determine the magnitude of the Ampere force received by the ν-shaped current-carrying wire.
The wire is bent into a ν shape with two equal sides each of length l and an included angle of 60°.
The total length of the wire is 2l.
The effective length of the wire that contributes to the Ampere force is the projection of the wire along the direction perpendicular to the magnetic field.
Since the wire forms a 60° angle, vector addition can be used to find the effective length.
Consider the two segments of the wire as vectors A and B, each of length l.
The resultant vector R of A and B can be found using the law of cosines: R = √(l² + l² - 2 * l * l * cos(120°)).
The Ampere force F on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by F = I L × B.
The effective length vector L is l√3 in the direction perpendicular to the magnetic field.
The magnitude of the force is F = I (l√3) B = Il√3 B.
The magnitude of the Ampere force received by the ν-shaped current-carrying wire is Il√3 B.
